book.title: Outliers: The Story of Success
book.description:
Learn what sets high achievers apart -- from Bill Gates to the Beatles -- in this #1 bestseller from "a singular talent" (New York Times Book Review).

In this stunning book, Malcolm Gladwell takes us on an intellectual journey through the world of "outliers"--the best and the brightest, the most famous and the most successful. He asks the question: what makes high-achievers different?

His answer is that we pay too much attention to what successful people are like, and too little attention to where they are from: that is, their culture, their family, their generation, and the idiosyncratic experiences of their upbringing. Along the way he explains the secrets of software billionaires, what it takes to be a great soccer player, why Asians are good at math, and what made the Beatles the greatest rock band.

Brilliant and entertaining, Outliers is a landmark work that will simultaneously delight and illuminate.

review.body:
I let Outliers accumulate dust on my bookshelf for too many months thanks to the misconception it would be more positive psychology, business-oriented, or self-help. Something about the way I first interpreted the blurb on the dust jacket made me think of The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People. After closer inspection, however, I found more ties between Gladwell’s writing and my sociology textbook.
Outliers reads like a collection of appropriate, well-researched, and well transitioned essays written by an applied sociology or applied psychology graduate and organized into two parts each exploring the importance of either opportunity or legacy.
In the first part, Opportunity, Gladwell unravels high level stories of achievement gathered through personal interviews with popular successful figures and prodigies emphasizing chance opportunities that were seized, in one way or another, by individuals ranging from “geniuses, business tycoons, rock stars, and software programmers” (p. 17).
Throughout the publication Gladwell points out how success is dependent on factors beyond hard work and perseverance to include adventitious opportunities and “cultural legacies” - drawing parallels to observations made by sociologist C. Wright Mills on the affluent heritage of business leaders in the 18th through 20th centuries (p. 63).
Outliers repeatedly suggests that successfulness should not be attributed to any one talent, skill, or innate ability, as popular success stories seem to imply. Through the example of Christopher Langan, the “smartest man in America” (Sager 1999, Fowler 2000, Wigmore 2000, and Brabham 2001), Gladwell shows how intellect has a threshold after which it loses the ability to effectively translate into any measurable real-world advantage (p. 79).
In an interview with Gladwell, Bill Gates attributes his own success to “an incredibly lucky series of events” (p. 55). By this point in the book I knew I was hooked. Fear of finding the typical, marketing-esque story of success is what had kept me from reading Outliers. Instead I found Gladwell stripping down each success story into a well-researched series of happenstance.
Outliers does well at not only summarizing these individuals and their ‘true’ path to success, but also to groups such as Canadian Hockey Leagues, KIPP public charter schools, and cultures such as the Chinese - whose Asian number-naming system provides inherent advantages over Western languages (p. 228).
Don’t make the same mistake I did and write Outliers off as something it is not. It is more than just business, organizational psychology, or applied sociology, and is an easy read without much unrecognizable jargon. Don’t read it expecting examples of how to become successful. Instead, let it give you perspective on how discipline, heritage, and a bit of luck can converge together into successfulness.
